and the economy required by the small amount of money to
be placed at tho disposal of the committee, forbade.
The executive committee, however, took early measures
to secure the services of an able and experienced engineer,
when he should be required,—such a one as would meet the
wishes and views expressed by members of the Convention,
during its session in June.
When the time arrived to set the surveyor at work, the
money to meet the expense to be incurred, was not ready,
through no fault however, of this committee, as has been
shown.
The active steps now being taken, will, it is confidently believed, secure the completion of the requisite surveys and
estimates before the assembling of the Convention.
Thus much, as to the performance ofthe specific duties imposed upon the executive committee. Its members
have individually endeavored to promote the interests ofthe
enterprise.
Messrs. Lanfear and Stanton while at the north, during
the Summer, devoted much time and attention to the examination of railroads, They travelled over most ofthe northern
and eastern roads, making attentive observations and careful
inquiries in regard to their construction, cost, management,
business, profits, the employment of engineers, &c, and
obtained a great amount of valuable information for the be«
Befit of this enterprise in which their confidence is confirmed, and to the completion of which they are now more thSn
ever devoted.
It has been asked, why the executive committee do not
bring the subject of this rail-road before the people in the
Public prints.
